questions.question: The peripheral smear finding of a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of fever and lymphadenopathy, along with the peripheral smear findings, is most consistent with infectious mononucleosis.

questions.question: Bruton tyrosine kinase is involved in which type of B-cell lymphoma?
questions.explanation: Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) is associated with B-cell chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Tumor cells in CLL rely on signals generated by the B-cell receptor for growth and survival. These signals are transduced by a cascade of kinases that include BTK. Note: BTK is also defective in patients with congenital X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a 'convent-girl' appearance. Peripheral smear of chronic lymphocytic leukemia showing smudge cells. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the Western world. The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL: <5000 per mm³. It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen. Total blood count: Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections. 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells. Peripheral smear: Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears. Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a 'convent-girl' appearance. Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both). Lymph node biopsy: Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates. Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL. The chromosomal defects: Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis). Deletion of 11q. Trisomy 12q. Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).

questions.question: The neoplastic cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma originate from which of the following?
questions.explanation: The cell of origin for chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) is either a post-germinal center memory B cell or a naive B cell. The cells of CLL show both unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) and somatically hypermutated Ig segments (those of post-germinal center memory B cell). Tumors with unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a genetic anomaly seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/small lymphocytic lymphoma?
questions.explanation: Deletion of 17p is a genetic anomaly seen in chronic lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL)/small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL), not trisomy 17p. The genetic anomalies seen in CLL/SLL are: • Trisomy 12 • Deletion of 13q • Deletion of 17p (bad prognosis) • Deletion of 11q (bad prognosis)

questions.question: A 70-year-old man presents with weakness and generalized lymphadenopathy. Lymph node biopsy shows diffuse effacement with small lymphocytes and proliferation centers. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Lymph node biopsy in CLL/SLL shows effacement of normal nodal architecture by sheets of predominantly small lymphocytes. They have round to slightly irregular nuclei, condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Admixed are a variable number of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates referred to as proliferation centers. These contain mitotically active cells. When present, proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL/SLL (also known as a pseudofollicular pattern). The image given below shows a lymph node biopsy of CLL in a low-power view. It shows loss of normal architecture and a large, pale-staining area in the center of the node (a proliferation center). Lymph node biopsy of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Lymph node biopsy of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Lymph node biopsy showing pseudofollicles in CLL. Lymph node biopsy showing pseudofollicles in CLL.

questions.question: A 58-year-old man with cervical lymphadenopathy is suspected to have chronic lymphocytic leukemia. What should be the absolute lymphocyte count/mm^3 to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation: The diagnostic requirement for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is an absolute lymphocyte count >5000 per cubic millimeter. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytosis: CLL - 5000/mm^3, SLL - <5000 cells/mm^3. Note: CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the Western world.

questions.question: Flow cytometric analysis of four patients is given below. Who among the following is most likely suffering from chronic lymphocytic leukemia?

options.D: Patient 4 CD23 CD5 Patient 1 CD5 Patient 3 BONE MARROW CD23 CD5 Patient 2 CD5 Patient 4

questions.explanation: Small lymphocytes of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) are CD23 and CD5 positive. Hence, the flow cytometry of Patient 1 (CD23 and CD5 positive) correctly represents the phenotype of CLL. The tumor cells also express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20. Low-level expression of surface Ig (usually IgM or IgM and IgD) is also typical. Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results: Flow Cytometry interpretation Antigen B being checked on cells +243 Antigen A being checked on cells + BONE MARROW Interpretation of results: Quadrant 1 - Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen Quadrant 2 - Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens. Quadrant 3 - Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens Quadrant 4 - Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

questions.question: A 73-year-old man came with complaints of malaise and low-grade fever. He had generalized lymphadenopathy. The histopathological examination of the lymph node is as shown below. These cells showed positivity for CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Which of the following does not indicate a poor prognosis in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The presence of NOTCH1 mutation is associated with a poor prognosis in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The histopathological image shows small, darker staining lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli, which are typically seen in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). Variables that correlate with a worse outcome include: the presence of deletions of 11q and 17p, lack of somatic hypermutation, expression of ZAP-70, and presence of NOTCH1 mutations.

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presented with chronic fatigue and generalized lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed overexpression of BCL2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. This condition is associated with overexpression of BCL2. It usually presents in middle age as painless generalized lymphadenopathy. The involvement of extranodal sites is relatively uncommon. It has an indolent waxing and waning course. In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The median survival rate is for 7-9 years. The cell of origin for follicular lymphoma is germinal centre B cells. It shows (14;18) translocation. Lymph node biopsy shows closely packed follicles. Centrocytes (small cells with a cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm) and centroblasts (large cells with open nuclear chromatin and multiple nucleoli) are seen. Bone marrow is involved in 85% of the cases and shows para-trabecular lymphoid aggregates.

questions.question: Which of the following chromosomal abnormality is likely to be seen in patients withfollicular lymphoma?
questions.explanation: Follicular lymphoma shows t(14;18).Its hallmark is a translocation that juxtaposes the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2locus on chromosome 18. It is seen in up to 90% of follicular lymphomas and leads tooverexpression of BCL2.BCL2 inhibits apoptosis and promotes the survival of follicular lymphoma cells.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. Lymph node biopsy shows the following picture. Which of the following is not true for this condition?

options.D: Possible transformation into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.explanation: The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and a very small inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. Lymph node biopsy of follicular lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent, waxing and waning course, not an aggressive course. Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown below. Immunophenotyping: The cell of origin is a germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and surface Ig. BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases. Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases. Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy, and shows BCL-6 positivity.

questions.question: A patient with longstanding cervical lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma. What is the cell of origin for this condition?
questions.explanation: Mantle-cell lymphoma arises from the mantle-zone B cells, which are naive B cells as they lack somatic hypermutation of the IgH gene. Mantle-cell lymphomas have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and overexpression of cyclin D1. It is CD5 positive and CD23 negative. Comparison between mantle-cell lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL): Mantle cell lymphoma CLL/SLL CD5 Positive Positive CD23 Negative Positive Cyclin D1 Positive Negative Mantle cell lymphoma CLL/SLL FMC7 Positive Negative CD10, BCL6 Negative Negative

questions.question: Which of the following statements about mantle cell lymphoma is false?

options.B: Most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy
options.C: Associated with overexpression of cyclin D1
options.D: Tumor cells are CD5 + and CD23 +

questions.explanation: The neoplastic cells in mantle cell lymphoma are CD5 positive and CD23 negative. Mantle cell lymphoma usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. Centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, differentiating it from chronic lymphocytic lymphoma. Immunophenotyping reveals the cells expressing cyclin D1, CD5, CD19, CD20, surface Ig. CD23 is negative in these cells.

questions.question: A 53-year-old man was evaluated for painless lymphadenopathy. Biopsy showed a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclear contours. Which translocation is seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture and pathological findings point toward the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma. The lymph node biopsy typically shows proliferation consisting of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes. The nuclei of these cells have irregular or deeply cleaved contours. Mantle cell lymphoma has a t(11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. Option A: Follicular lymphoma has t(14;18), not t(18;14). Hence, it is not the answer.

questions.question: A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has t(11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Translocation (11;14) is characteristic of mantle cell lymphoma. The markers to be done to confirm the diagnosis are Sox11 and Cyclin D1. Mantle cell lymphoma is seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life and has a male predominance. It is characterized by painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. In some cases, there is multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon known as lymphomatoid polyposis. It has (11;14) translocation. Lymph node biopsy shows nodal tumor cells may surround reactive germinal centers. A homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours is typically seen. Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively. Immunophenotyping is positive for cyclin D and SOX-11. SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 index (<10%). Other markers include: CD 5, CD19, and CD20 +ve, CD 23 -ve, moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain). The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

questions.question: What is the immunohistochemistry marker for cyclin D1-negative mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.explanation: SOX11 is the marker used for cyclin D1-negative mantle cell lymphoma. Note: MYD88 is a marker for Waldenström's macroglobulinemia.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about marginal zone lymphoma is false?

options.A: They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders
options.B: They spread rapidly to other sites
options.C: They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated
options.D: Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma may occur

questions.explanation: Marginal zone lymphoma does not spread rapidly to other sites. It remains localized for prolonged periods and spreads systematically in the later course of the disease. They are B-cell tumours that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. It is the most common primary extranodal lymphoma. They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or infectious aetiology: • Salivary gland in Sjögren disease • Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditis • Stomach in Helicobacter gastritis. They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated. Antibiotic therapy directed against Helicobacter pylori leads to tumour regression. Translocations associated with MALToma are t(11;18), t(14;18), and t(1;14). These translocations then upregulate BCL-10/MALT1, a protein that activates NF-kB and promotes the growth and survival of B-cells. They may invade epithelial structures to form lymphoepithelial lesions. Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma may occur.

questions.question: A patient with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis was noted to have a swelling in thethyroid region. After evaluation, it was diagnosed as a marginal zone lymphoma. What is thecell of origin of this lymphoma?
questions.explanation: 529Marginal zone lymphomas are considered to be of memory B cell origin. In most cases, they showevidence of somatic hypermutation.The category of marginal zone lymphoma encompasses a heterogeneous group of B cell tumoursthat arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. They are often referred to asMALTomas.

questions.question: A patient presents to you with rapidly growing swelling on her right cheek. Past history issignificant for Sjögren syndrome. You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in her. What is the mostprobable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Lymphomas arising in the setting of Sjögren syndrome in the salivary gland is marginal-zonelymphomas.They often arise in tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune orinfectious aetiology such as:•Salivary gland in Sjögren syndrome• Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditis•Stomach in Helicobacter gastritis.

questions.question: Which of the following translocations is seen in extra-nodal marginal-zone lymphoma?
questions.explanation: The translocation seen in marginal-zone lymphoma is t(11;18). Other translocations includet(14;18), t(1;14).Marginal-zone lymphoma begins as a polyclonal immune reaction. Signals from theantigen-stimulated T helper cells, drive the growth and survival of the clonal B-cells. At this stage,it is reversible, as in gastric MALToma after antibiotics against Helicobacter pylori.With time tumour cells may acquire mutations that render their growth and survivalantigen-independent. Translocations such as t(11;18), t(14;18), or t(1;14) up-regulate the expressionand function of BCL10 or MALT1 and promote the growth and survival of B cells.These translocations are relatively specific for extranodal marginal-zone lymphomas.

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman came with complaints of chronic lethargy and weakness. Completeblood counts revealed pancytopenia. The peripheral smear showed the following picture.Which of the following statements is false about this condition?513
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell neoplasm and not aT-cell lymphoma.The peripheral smear shows leukemic cells with fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projectionsas shown below.530Peripheral smear of hairy cell leukemiaDPatients present with massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia. There is an increased incidence ofatypical mycobacterial infections, possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia.Activating point mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF is seen in 90% of cases.Peripheral smear shows fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections which are bestrecognized under the phase-contrast microscope. The bone marrow aspirate produces a dry tap.A trephine biopsy reveals infiltration by the cancer cells often in the pattern of a honeycombappearance. Leukemic cells have nuclei surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo (fried egg appearance).The neoplastic cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).Markers for hairy cell leukemia include:⚫ pan-B-cell markers- CD 19, CD20•• CD11c• CD25• CD103• annexin A1

questions.question: A 65-year-old man with a dragging sensation in his abdomen is found to have massivesplenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear findings are as follows. Which of the followingmarkers would you test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The clinical features and peripheral smear showing fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairyprojections point towards the diagnosis of hairy cell leukaemia.It's a rare but distinctive neoplasm of the B cells where splenomegaly is often the only abnormalfinding. Pancytopenia from marrow involvement and sequestration of cells in the enlarged spleenis seen in half the cases and infections are seen in one-third of the affected patients.CD103 must be tested among the markers to confirm hairy cell leukaemia.Hairy-cell leukaemias typically express the following markers:531•Pan B-cell markers CD19, CD20, surface Ig (usually IgG)• CD11c• CD25.•CD103• Annexin A1.Annexin A1 is the most specific and sensitive marker.

questions.question: A histological specimen of the spleen is shown below. Which non-Hodgkin's lymphoma doesnot arise from the area marked as 1?
questions.explanation: The area marked '1' in the image is the white pulp of the spleen. Hairy-cell leukemia does not arisefrom the white pulp, it involves only the red pulp of the spleen. The other condition involving thered pulp is hepato-splenic lymphoma.All the other non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) involve white pulp.Splenomegaly is the most common and often the only abnormal physical finding in hairy-cellleukemia. The spleen in this condition is described as a beefy red spleen.The image given below shows the normal histology of the spleen.Histology of spleenTrabeculaWhite pulpRed pulp

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman presented with generalized itching and mild hypoaesthesia of the skin.On examination, maculopapular patches were seen on her back. Biopsy revealed the presenceof atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei infiltrating the dermis and epidermis. Whatis the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given pathological feature is characteristic of a Pautrier's microabscess. These are seen inmycosis fungoides.It is a mature, cutaneous, CD4+ T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Skin lesions include truncalscaling, red-brown patches, plaques, and fungating nodules. Lesions may evolve into a systemiclymphoma, with visceral and nodal spread.532Sezary syndrome is a variant of mycosis fungoides. It is the leukemic seeding of blood bymalignant T cells from the skin (CD4+). It presents with diffuse erythroderma and scaling.Histological hallmark includes:•-⚫ Sézary-Lutzner cells cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclearmembrane).• Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.⚫ Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.

questions.question: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma. The peripheral blood smearshows the following cell. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards adiagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells.Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper Tcells that are home to the skin.Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goesinto tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells.In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cellswith the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progressionoccurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The diseaseprogresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.

questions.question: You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in a patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis.On workup, she has splenomegaly and her blood count showed neutropenia andlymphocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: 533A triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome.Some patients with Felty's syndrome have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlyingcause.Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a T-cell (CD3+) and NK-cell (CD56+) variantleukemia. They are associated with mutations in the transcription factor, STAT3.Patients usually presents with mild to moderate lymphocytosis and splenomegaly. Neutropeniaand anemia are also present. Lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly are usually absent.There is an increased incidence of rheumatological disorders associated with this condition.The peripheral smear picture shows large lymphocytes with abundant blue cytoplasm and fewazurophilic granules.534
